Empty Product
In a monoid, the empty product is defined as the unit element, i.e., $\prod_{i=1}^{0} a_{i} := e$, where $e$ is the unit element.
Cyclic group
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Units of a Ring
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
Product of Ideals

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Irreducible element

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.
System of generators
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Torsion submodule
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
Frobenius homomorphism

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.
Finite Field

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Element of a Set
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of an empty product in a monoid relies on the concept of a unit element, which is a specific element in a monoid.
A cyclic group is defined as a group generated by a single element, which implies the need for the concept of a group.
The units of a ring are defined as the multiplicatively invertible elements in a ring, which requires the concept of a ring.
The product of ideals is defined in the context of a ring, so the concept of a ring is necessary.
An irreducible element is defined in an integral domain, which is a specific type of ring, so the concept of a ring is necessary.
A system of generators is defined for an A-module, which is a generalization of a module over a ring, so the concept of a module is necessary.
The torsion submodule is defined for an A-module, so the concept of a module is necessary.
The Frobenius homomorphism is defined for a field of characteristic p>0, so the concept of a field is necessary.
A finite field is a specific type of field, so the concept of a field is necessary.
The Galois group of a field extension is defined in terms of field automorphisms, so the concept of a field is necessary.
